text: Raj had come a long way, though the road behind him no longer belonged to memory. His feet moved out of habit, not certainty.
The land stretched endlessly ahead—quiet, patient, uncaring. Every step felt rehearsed, as if he had once known where he was going.
He could not remember why the journey began. Only that stopping felt wrong.

choices.text: Notice the people walking beside him.

text: Along the road, others joined him. Travelers seeking shelter. Fighters chasing causes. Guides who spoke as if they knew the land intimately.
At night, fires were lit. Stories were told. Laughter flickered briefly, like sparks escaping into the dark.
Raj listened—but each voice felt distant, as though heard through water.
Morning came, and the road thinned.
One by one, the companions left—turning toward villages, borders, and lives that clearly belonged to them.
Raj did not ask them to stay. He was unsure if he even noticed when the last set of footsteps faded away.
The dragon waited at the end of the road, just as the stories promised.
Its presence was overwhelming—ancient, heavy, unquestioning. This was the obstacle meant to justify the journey.
Yet as Raj raised his weapon, no faces came to mind. No cheers. No fear. Only silence.
The dragon fell.
The land did not change. No songs were sung. No doors opened.
Raj stood alone among ruins, realizing victory had never been the thing he was searching for.
The spell book lay where it always had—silent, unassuming.
Every page was blank at first. Then faint markings appeared, responding not to magic, but to memory.
The book was never meant to hold power. It was meant to hold people.

choices.text: Write the names of those who walked beside you.

text: Raj returned to the road, but it no longer felt endless.
The journey was not about reaching the end—it was about remembering who had shaped the path.
And this time, he walked toward home.
